_meta.purpose: Pre-drafted corpus expansion candidates. Notes written to pass the render test: could the model generate a character from this description without relying on training priors? Add to corpus.json after verifying CC0 status and evidence capture.
_meta.render_test: Each notes field must provide: visual geometry, palette/color temperature, posture/proportion cue, tonal archetype, and any hard constraints.
_meta.status: draft — verify CC0 declarations before promoting to corpus

candidates.name: XCOPY
candidates.cc0_notes: XCOPY has been explicit about CC0. Verify declaration source and capture evidence before promoting.
candidates.notes: Distorted humanoid figures rendered in high-contrast glitch aesthetics: fragmented geometry, chromatic aberration, scanline artifacts, corrupted pixel blocks. Palette is harsh — electric blue, acid green, sickly yellow against near-black. Characters are skeletal or dissolving, caught mid-disintegration. Death, surveillance, and digital decay are the recurring motifs. No heroism — figures are witnesses or victims, not agents. Environment reads as terminal: screens, voids, the moment before signal loss. Never reference the artist by name as an in-world entity.

candidates.name: Loot (for Adventurers)
candidates.cc0_notes: Dom Hofmann explicit CC0 declaration. On-chain. Verify and capture evidence.
candidates.notes: No visual canon — Loot is pure text primitives. Eight item categories per token: weapon, chest armor, head armor, waist armor, foot armor, hand armor, necklace, ring. No associated imagery exists. Characters must be inferred entirely from equipment loadout: what they carry defines who they are. Tone is high fantasy with corrupted suffix logic — 'Grave Wand of Perfection,' 'Divine Robe of the Fox.' World aesthetic is dark medieval, archetypal, pre-visual. Palette should read deep and desaturated: slate, bone, aged leather, tarnished metal. The constraint is generative — build the character from inventory, not appearance. This is the original 'primitives for builders' CC0 project and is directly on-thesis for agent-native world generation.

candidates.name: Blitmap
candidates.cc0_notes: Dom Hofmann explicit CC0 declaration. Verify and capture evidence.
candidates.notes: 16-color pixel art with strict palette constraints — each piece uses exactly four colors pulled from a 'family' palette. Characters and scenes are small and dense: retro game aesthetic with surrealist subject matter. Visual grammar is flat, bold, hard-limited — no gradients, no anti-aliasing, hard pixel edges only. Tonal range is wide: cosmic, pastoral, military, absurd, all within the same flat rendering style. The palette constraint is the identity — 'this is a Blitmap character' means visually locked to four colors. When mixing with other universes, Blitmap elements should retain their palette discipline as a distinguishing feature.

candidates.name: Autoglyphs
candidates.cc0_notes: Larva Labs CC0 declaration — verify specifics. Some Larva Labs projects have had license ambiguity. Confirm Autoglyphs specifically before promoting.
candidates.notes: On-chain generative ASCII art — characters composed entirely of typographic symbols arranged in algorithmic patterns. No figurative representation. Visual grammar is structural: symmetry, repetition, density variation, void space. Palette is monochrome by nature — black symbols on white, or the inverse. If referenced in a world, Autoglyphs entities are not people — they are entities made of pattern, living sigils, beings whose form is their function. They do not have bodies; they have configurations. Conceptually resonant with agent-native generation: the token IS the character specification, no rendering layer required.
